newsitem.title: USA: U.S. banks seen thriving under looser reins.
newsitem.headline: U.S. banks seen thriving under looser reins.

text.p: A loosening of regulations that will permit U.S. banks easier entry into other financial service businesses is bullish for the banks, analysts said.

Bank stocks, which have for decades traded at a discount to the market valuation for stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500 index, will command a price-to-earnings multiple closer to the S&P, said Robert Bonelli, executive vice president at Ernst & Co.
He said as banks shift their revenue mix away from interest-sensitive businesses, earnings will increase and higher valuations will create a "multiplying effect."

"What banks really want is to provide a whole litany and array of financial solutions to corporate and business customers," said Anthony Davis, analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds. He said surveys have shown that U.S. consumers also want to buy insurance and other services through banks.

The latest victory for the banks in their rivalry with securities firms and insurance companies was an announcement by Comptroller of the Currency Eugene Ludwig of a new rule that could allow banks on an individual basis to conduct new activities through subsidiaries.
Davis noted that the debate about who should be allowed to do what in the U.S. financial services industry has become the object of a turf war between various groups in Washington.

"The Fed has been loosening revenue restrictions (on the amount of underwriting in a securities affiliate of a bank) in step-like fashion since 1989," he said. "Along comes Gene Ludwig who has clearly been the most proactive comptroller that we've had in 20 years saying 'if you're nationally-chartered, send us your application.'"
Davis also noted that the U.S. Congress, which failed to resolve the problem in 1996, is expected to try again in 1997.
While the American Bankers Association praised the rule, the American Couincil of Life Insurance said it would "mount a major effort" to block the action.

The Securities Industry Association (SIA), trade group for brokers and investment banks, said the OCC move was "a misguided step because it will only benefit part of the financial services industry." Steve Judge, senior vice

president for government affairs, said Congress should do the job of re-shaping the financial services. He said the OCC move will allow banks to own full-service securities firms but securities firms will not be able to own banks.
Davis said while the turf battles may have slowed reform earlier this year, with the OCC's move today "right now it seems to be accelrating things."

The analyst said it is clear that "the banking industry is going to build or buy these businesses." He noted that NationsBank Corp, First Union Corp and others have been importing talent from Wall Street to build investment banking businsses.

First Union agreed in September to acquire Keystone Investments Inc, a large asset manager. And Barnett Banks Inc earlier this year won a key court decision allowing it to sell insurance in small towns.

Bonelli noted that Minneapolis-based Norwest Corp is grandfathered into the insurance brokerage business and derives as much as 25 percent of its earnings from this activity. "It's one of the top performing banks in the country," he said.

Thomas Andes, chairman and chief executive of St. Louis-based banking company Magna Group Inc, told Reuters in an interview this week that he sees the banking branch of the future as a facility offering "total financial services, be it brokerage, insurance or whatever, a 'financial retail store.'"
